q: What is Turner syndrome?
a: Turner syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects females and is characterized by having only one normal X sex chromosome instead of two.

q: What are the characteristics of Turner syndrome?
a: Females with Turner syndrome often have shorter height, underdeveloped ovaries leading to infertility, and delayed sexual development.

q: When is Turner syndrome usually diagnosed in girls?
a: Turner syndrome is often diagnosed when a girl fails to show sexual development associated with puberty, typically between the ages of 8 and 14 years.

q: Is there a cure for Turner syndrome?
a: There is no cure for Turner syndrome, but many of the associated symptoms can be treated.

q: What aspects of the body should be regularly checked for individuals with Turner syndrome?
a: Individuals with Turner syndrome should have regular check-ups for their heart, kidneys, and reproductive system.

q: Is life expectancy affected by Turner syndrome?
a: Life expectancy for individuals with Turner syndrome is slightly reduced, but regular health checks can help improve it by identifying and treating potential problems early.

q: What is the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service?
a: The National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service (NCARDRS) is a registry that collects information about individuals with Turner syndrome to support research and improve prevention and treatment.

q: Can individuals opt out of the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service?
a: Yes, individuals with Turner syndrome can choose to opt out of the National Congenital Anomaly and Rare Disease Registration Service at any time.

q: How often should individuals with Turner syndrome have their health checked?
a: Individuals with Turner syndrome should have regular health checks throughout their lives to monitor potential problems.

q: Can Turner syndrome be prevented?
a: Turner syndrome cannot be prevented as it occurs randomly during conception.
